raw_text:
Yachvili savours France comeback
 
 France scrum-half Dimitri Yachvili praised his team after they fought back to beat England 18-17 in the Six Nations clash at Twickenham.
 
 Yachvili kicked all of France's points as they staged a second-half revival. "We didn't play last week against Scotland and we didn't play in the first half against England," he said. "But we're very proud to beat England at Twickenham. We were just defending in the first half and we said we had to put them under pressure. We did well." Yachvili admitted erratic kicking from England's Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley, who missed six penalties and a drop goal chance between them, had been decisive. "I know what it's like with kicking. When you miss some it's very hard mentally, but it went well for us," he said. France captain Fabien Pelous insisted his side never doubted they could secure their first win against England at Twickenham since 1997. France were 17-6 down at half-time, but Pelous said: "No-one was down at half-time, we were still confident. "We said we only had 11 points against us, which was not much. "The plan was to keep hold of possession and pressure England to losing their composure." France coach Bernard Laporte accepted his side had not played well. "We know we have to play better to defend the title," he said. "I'm not happy we didn't score a try but we're happy because we won."
llama3.2:1b: Dimitri Yachvili led France's comeback against England, kicking all points in the second half. He acknowledged England's poor kicking from Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley, which were decisive factors in their victory.
llama3.2:3b: France's Dimitri Yachvili praised his team after beating England 18-17 at Twickenham, with erratic English kicking decisions being key to France's comeback. France captain Fabien Pelous said the side never doubted their ability to win, while coach Bernard Laporte accepted that his team needed to play better to defend the title.
gemma2:2b: Dimitri Yachvili scored all of France's points, as they beat England 18-17 at Twickenham in their Six Nations clash.  France fought back from a halftime deficit to win the game, aided by inaccurate English kicking, with captain Fabien Pelous expressing confidence throughout. Coach Bernard Laporte acknowledged their performance was not good but stressed the victory as a positive outcome.
qwen2.5:0.5b: France’s Yachvili praised the team after winning 18-17 against England in the Six Nations clash at Twickenham. He emphasized his team's resilience and determination, particularly with their second-half revival. Yachvili noted that despite not playing well in the opening stages, they were still confident of winning due to their defensive strategy and the fact they had pressure on England’s defense. Despite missing penalties and scoring a drop goal, France maintained possession and pushed England into a losing position, leading to the victory.
qwen2.5:1.5b: France's scrum-half Dimitri Yachvili praised their comeback victory over England 18-17 at Twickenham, with his performance as France's sole kicker being key to the victory. Despite missing several penalties and drop goals, he maintained confidence throughout, stating he handled missed kicks well. The match ended 24-6 in favor of England but was crucial for France's comeback. Captain Fabien Pelous affirmed their ability to win at Twickenham, despite their poor second-half performance against Scotland. Coach Bernard Laporte acknowledged the need for improvement and a better defensive strategy but highlighted the importance of winning.
qwen2.5:3b: France scrum-half Dimitri Yachvili praised his team for their comeback victory against England in the Six Nations, winning 18-17 at Twickenham. Yachvili credited France's second-half performance and emphasized that they were just defending in the first half until they put pressure on England. He admitted the decisive factor was England's poor kicking from players Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley who missed several penalties and drop goals. Captain Fabien Pelous stated their side never doubted victory despite a 17-6 halftime deficit, believing they only had to defend against 11 points. France coach Bernard Laporte acknowledged his team needed to improve for future defense of the title but expressed happiness with the win.

Yachvili kicked all of France's points as they staged a second-half revival with "We didn't play last week against Scotland and we didn't play in the first half against England." The game was a decisive victory, marking France's victory over England since 1997 when they were 17-6 down at half-time. However, Yachvili admitted erratic kicking from England's Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley who missed six penalties and a drop goal chance between them had been decisive.
smollm:1.7b: France scrum-half Dimitri Yachvili praised his team after they fought back to beat England 18-17 in the Six Nations clash at Twickenham.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Yachvili's performance against England in the Six Nations game. Let me read through it carefully.

First, Yachvili is praising his team after they fought back. He called him "savours" France's comeback. That sounds good because it shows he really likes how he's doing and maybe a bit of humor about it.

Then there's some details about the game itself: they scored 18 points against England's 17. That's a big win. Yachvili kicked all his team's points in the second half, which makes sense because often teams have more goals late. He said they didn't play last week against Scotland and in the first half of England's game, they had to put England under pressure by missing some penalties and dropping a goal chance. That shows England was struggling early on.

Yachvili admitted his team had erratic kicking from England, Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley. They missed six penalties and had one drop chance, which made him say he knows it's hard mentally but they handled it well. 

France's captain, Pelous, said they never doubted their first win against England since 1997, even though they were down 17-6 at half-time. He emphasized confidence and a plan to hold onto possession to pressure England into composure.

Yachvili admitted the game wasn't easy but was happy because they won. His coach Laporte said they need to play better to defend their title and is happy since they secured that win.

Putting this all together, I need to make sure I include Yachvili's praise, his team's strong performance, England's early struggles, the kickers' mistakes, France's confidence, and his satisfaction with the outcome. I also need to mention Laporte's feedback on their defensive play.
</think>

Yachvili praised his team for their comeback against England in the Six Nations game, emphasizing their strong performance despite a late push. England struggled early, missing penalties and dropping goal chances, while Yachvili acknowledged his team's erratic kicking from Hodgson and Barkley. France remained confident, knowing they secured their first win since 1997 at half-time. Yachvili admitted the game wasn't easy but was content with their hard win. His coach Laporte recommended improvements to defend their title.
tinyllama:1.1b: Dimitri Yačiveli hailed his team after they managed to secure a comeback in the Six Nations by beating England at Twickenham, and he praised their defensive efforts that led to the victory. He also highlighted that they were able to win despite committing some errors in kicking from Charlie Hoğgson and Olly Barklay, two of England's kickers who scored six penalties and a drop goal each. Despite being down at half-time with a 17-6 deficit, France captain Fabien Pelous insisted that their team remained confident, believing that they could secure their first win against England since 1997 at Twickenham. Laporte admitted that his side had not played well but was happy to have secured the title, despite not scoring a try in the game.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The France rugby team fought back against England, with Yachvili scoring all of France's points in a crucial Six Nations match at Twickenham Stadium. Despite missing several kick opportunities during the first half, France kept up their pressure and scored a try after taking charge of possession. However, England found themselves down 17-6 midway through the second half and needed to claw their way back in order to secure their first win against the French since 1997. Pelous described his team's performance as "very proud," emphasizing that they were not down during the defeat. Fabien Pelous insisted that his side was never in doubt, maintaining their confidence despite being two points behind at halftime. Overall, France's coach Laporte acknowledged that the team needed to improve their performance, stating, "We know we have to play better to defend the title."
phi:2.7b: Dimitri Yachvili praised his team for their comeback in France's win against England at Twickenham, scoring all of France's points. France were 17-6 down at half-time, but Pelous and Laporte remained confident in their ability to secure the Six Nations title. They had a plan to keep hold of possession and pressure England to losing their composure, despite not playing well overall.

Fabien Pelous emphasized his side's confidence despite being down 17-6 at half-time, and Bernard Laporte acknowledged that they did not play well but still won the game.
hermes3:3b: Dimitr Yachvili praises France's comeback victory over England in Six Nations, highlighting improved defensive pressure and pride in beating England at Twickenham.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Dimitri Yachvili, France's scrum-half, praised his team after they came back from 17-6 deficit to defeat England 18-17 in the Six Nations clash at Twickenham. Yachvili scored all of France's points in the second half and credited erratic kicking from England's Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley for being decisive. France captain Fabien Pelous affirmed that his side never doubted they could secure their first win against England at Twickenham since 1997. Although France coach Bernard Laporte admitted his team hadn't played well, he expressed satisfaction in the victory as they aim to defend their title.

granite3.1-dense:2b: After a lackluster performance in their previous matches, France secured their first victory over England at Twickenham since 1997, 18-17. Key to their success was England's inconsistent kicking, with Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley missing several attempts. Despite being 17-6 down at halftime, France maintained confidence and executed a game plan focused on retaining possession and unsettling the opposition. The team's captain, Fabien Pelous, emphasized their unwavering belief in their ability to win. France coach Bernard Laporte acknowledged his side's subpar performance but expressed satisfaction with the win, recognizing they must improve to defend their Six Nations title.
